description: The stuff things are made of.

slides.title: What is Materials Science?
slides.content:
# The Ingredients üß¨

Understanding relations between Structure, Properties, and Processing of materials.
- Metals, Ceramics, Polymers, Composites.

slides.title: Material Properties
slides.content:
# Behavior üß™

- **Mechanical**: Strength, Ductility (stretch), Hardness.
- **Thermal**: Conductivity, Expansion.
- **Electrical**: Conductor, Insulator, Semiconductor.

slides.title: Structure: Atomic
slides.content:
# Crystal Lattice üíé

How atoms are packed.
- **Crystalline**: Ordered grid (Metals). Strong.
- **Amorphous**: Random mess (Glass). Brittle.

slides.title: Metals
slides.content:
# Shiny & Strong ‚öîÔ∏è

- Sea of electrons (conducts electricity).
- **Alloys**: Mixing metals for better properties.
- **Steel**: Iron + Carbon.
- **Bronze**: Copper + Tin.

slides.title: Ceramics
slides.content:
# Hard & Brittle üè∫

Clay, Glass, Porcelain.
- High melting point.
- Insulators.
- **Advanced Ceramics**: Used in spaceships and artificial bones.

slides.title: Polymers
slides.content:
# Long Chains üîó

Plastics and Rubbers.
- Made of organics (Carbon/Hydrogen).
- Lightweight, cheap, moldable.
- **Elastomers**: Rubber that bounces back.

slides.title: Mix Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: An alloy is a mixture involving at least one:

slides.title: Composites
slides.content:
# Best of Both ü•™

Combine two materials.
- **Carbon Fiber**: Fabric in glue. Extremely strong and light.
- **Concrete**: Stones in cement.
- **Fiberglass**: Glass wool in plastic.

slides.title: Stress-Strain Curve
slides.content:
# Breaking Point üìâ

The Graph of Engineering.
- **Elastic Region**: Bounces back.
- **Yield Point**: Permanently bent.
- **Fracture Point**: Snap.

slides.title: Failure Mechanisms
slides.content:
# Why stuff breaks üíî

- **Fatigue**: Repeated small stress leads to crack (Paperclip bending).
- **Creep**: Slow stretch under heat (Turbine blades).
- **Impact**: Sudden blow.

slides.title: Corrosion
slides.content:
# Rust üçÇ

Material reacting with environment.
- Iron $\to$ Rust (Oxidation).
- Prevention: Painting, Galvanizing (Zinc coating), Stainless Steel.

slides.title: Nanomaterials
slides.content:
# Tiny Tech üî¨

Materials at nanoscale (1-100nm).
- **Graphene**: Single layer of carbon. Strongest material known.
- **Carbon Nanotubes**: Super wires.
- Quantum Dots: TV screens.

slides.title: Semiconductors
slides.content:
# Silicon üíª

Basis of electronics.
- Conducts only when told to.
- Doping (adding impurities) controls conductivity.
- Moore's Law depends on making these smaller.

slides.title: Nano Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Graphene is made of a single layer of which element?

slides.title: Biomaterials
slides.content:
# Body Parts ü¶¥

Materials compatible with body.
- Titanium hips.
- Contact lenses.
- Dissolvable stitches.

slides.title: Smart Materials
slides.content:
# Magic ‚ú®

Response to stimuli.
- **Shape Memory Alloy**: Returns to shape when heated (Nitinol).
- **Piezoelectric**: Squeezing creates electricity (Lighters).

slides.title: Recycling
slides.content:
# Circular Economy ‚ôªÔ∏è

- Metals: Easy to melt and reuse.
- Thermoplastics: Can be reused.
- Thermosets/Composites: Very hard to recycle (Wind turbine blades).

slides.title: Processing
slides.content:
# Making It üî®

- **Annealing**: Heating to soften metal.
- **Quenching**: Rapid cooling to harden metal (Sword making).
- **Sintering**: Powdering and baking ceramics.

slides.title: Materials Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- Structure determines Property.
- **Steel** builds cities.
- **Silicon** builds brains.
- **Plastics** are everywhere.
- New materials = New tech.
